newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan economy shows steady signs of recovery.
newsitem.headline: Japan economy shows steady signs of recovery.

text.p: Japan's economy posted steady growth in the three months to the end of December and for calendar 1996, confirming that a gradual recovery is still in motion, the government said on Thursday.

The nation's gross domestic product (GDP) -- total output of goods and services minus net income from overseas production -- rose a real 1.0 percent in the October-December period from the previous quarter, or an annualised 3.9 percent.
This compared with a revised quarter-on-quarter GDP rise of 0.3 percent for the July-September quarter.

In calendar 1996, the nation's GDP -- a closely watched pointer to the health of the economy -- rose a real 3.6 percent from the previous year after a revised figure of 1.4 percent growth in 1995, the Economic Planning Agency (EPA) said.

Economists polled by Reuters ahead of the announcement had predicted, on average, that October-December GDP would rise by 0.8 percent quarter-on-quarter. The forecasts had ranged from 0.3 percent to 1.2 percent growth. They had expected GDP to grow by more than three percent for calendar 1996.
Although the data confirmed that the economy was improving, economists said it was still too early to judge whether solid recovery had really taken hold.
